What kind of places do you like travelin: I usually go for places that have a good mix of food, local life, and things to wander around — small cities or neighborhoods where you can get lost in markets, cafés, and little museums. And because I’ve lived in English-speaking countries a long time, I enjoy spots where I can flip between Japanese and English and notice the cultural differences — like the contrast between Kyoto’s old alleys and a laid-back European neighborhood, or Hokkaido’s wide open nature versus a city with a great coffee scene. Do you enjoy traveling alone?:
Yeah—I do, more often than not. Traveling alone gives me this strange kind of freedom: I can wake up and decide where to go without checking anyone else’s schedule, linger in a museum for hours, or veer down a random side street just because it looks interesting. Being bilingual helps a lot too; I’m usually less anxious about getting around or striking up conversations with locals, so solo trips feel less isolating and more like deliberate immersion.

That said, it’s not all romantic—dinner alone can feel a bit quiet sometimes, and there are moments I wish I had someone to share a particularly beautiful view or a ridiculous travel mishap with. For certain trips, like a festival or a multi-person road trip, I definitely prefer company. But for recharging, exploring at my own pace, and meeting new people on the road, I love solo travel.

Have you tried learning a new language?:
Totally — I’ve tried learning a few beyond Japanese and English. English I picked up by living in an English-speaking country, then later I tried brushing up on Spanish and a bit of French. Spanish stuck the best because I used it with friends, watched shows, and forced myself to speak right away. French was more on-and-off — I enjoyed the music and reading, but didn’t get the same amount of real conversation time, so progress was slower.

What helped most was doing things I enjoyed in the language: music, TV, messing around on social media, and short conversations with native speakers. The hardest part was getting over the fear of sounding clumsy — early on I would often understand more than I could produce. Little habits like shadowing (repeating aloud), language exchanges, and using the language daily made a big difference.
